Tomato_Bacterial_spot.name: Bacterial Spot
Tomato_Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot causes small, dark brown spots with yellow halos on leaves. It can severely reduce plant vigor and fruit quality.
solutions: Apply copper-based bactericides early in the season
Remove and destroy infected plant material immediately
Avoid overhead watering to reduce leaf wetness
Ensure good air circulation around plants
Use pathogen-free seeds and transplants
Practice crop rotation with non-solanaceous crops

Tomato_Early_blight.name: Early Blight
Tomato_Early_blight.description: Early blight appears as dark spots with concentric rings on older leaves. It spreads upward and can cause significant defoliation.
solutions: Apply fungicide treatments containing chlorothalonil or copper
Remove affected lower leaves immediately
Improve air circulation by proper plant spacing
Water at soil level to keep leaves dry
Clean up plant debris at end of season
Rotate crops to break disease cycle

Tomato_Late_blight.name: Late Blight
Tomato_Late_blight.description: Late blight causes water-soaked spots that quickly turn brown and black. It can destroy entire plants within days in humid conditions.
solutions: Apply preventive fungicides before symptoms appear
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Increase air circulation and reduce humidity
Avoid overhead watering completely
Disinfect tools between plants
Monitor weather for favorable disease conditions

Tomato_Leaf_Mold.name: Leaf Mold
Tomato_Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold appears as yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces with fuzzy growth underneath. Common in humid greenhouse conditions.
solutions: Improve ventilation to reduce humidity
Maintain temperature above 70Â°F when possible
Water at soil level only
Remove affected leaves promptly
Apply fungicides if necessary
Space plants properly for air circulation

Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.name: Septoria Leaf Spot
Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot creates small, circular spots with dark borders and light centers. It typically starts on lower leaves.
solutions: Use fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper
Remove and destroy affected lower leaves
Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash
Water at ground level to keep foliage dry
Clean up garden debris regularly
Practice 3-4 year crop rotation

Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.name: Spider Mites
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.description: Spider mites cause stippling, yellowing, and fine webbing on leaves. They thrive in hot, dry conditions.
solutions: Increase humidity around plants
Spray leaves with water to dislodge mites
Encourage beneficial insects like ladybugs
Use insecticidal soap or neem oil
Provide shade during hottest part of day
Monitor regularly for early detection

Tomato__Target_Spot.name: Target Spot
Tomato__Target_Spot.description: Target spot creates circular lesions with concentric rings resembling a target. It affects leaves, stems, and fruits.
solutions: Apply preventive fungicide treatments
Remove infected plant material immediately
Improve air circulation between plants
Avoid overhead irrigation
Remove plant debris from garden
Rotate with non-solanaceous crops

Tomato__Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.name: Yellow Leaf Curl Virus
Tomato__Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.description: This virus causes upward curling of leaves, yellowing, and stunted growth. It spreads through whiteflies.
solutions: Control whitefly populations immediately
Remove and destroy infected plants
Use reflective mulches to deter whiteflies
Plant resistant varieties when available
Disinfect hands and tools between plants
Use row covers during vulnerable periods

Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.name: Tomato Mosaic Virus
Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Mosaic virus causes mottled light and dark green patterns on leaves and stunted growth. It spreads through contact and contaminated tools.
solutions: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Disinfect tools and hands after handling plants
Control aphid and other insect vectors
Use virus-free seeds and resistant varieties
Avoid working with wet plants
Wear gloves when handling plants

Tomato_healthy.name: Healthy Plant
Tomato_healthy.description: Your plant appears to be healthy with no visible signs of disease. Keep up the good care!
solutions: Continue your current care routine
Monitor plants regularly for any changes
Maintain proper watering and nutrition
Ensure good air circulation
Keep practicing preventive measures
Schedule regular plant health checkups
